page.title: 04LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Rode heath is in the parish of Odd Rode.Odd Rode used to be part of Macclesfield Forest.In old English Rode or "Rod"meant a clearing.Odd derives from the name of a person thought to be a man named Hod hence Hod's Rod became Odd Rode. Scholar Green derives its name from the way in which farms were written in the time of Edward 1.(Scolehalc or Scolal)These terms are Scandinavian in origin which can be explained by the Wirral and surrounding areas being places of fairly intense viking settlement.The Green part is self explanatory. Rode Heath had been important for the production of salt for over two hundred years.The opening of the Trent and Mersey canal led to an expansion of the community.This industry has ceased and so have the salt workings.
